items.title: Moonvalley launches an AI video generator built for moviemaking
items.author: Naeem Talukdar
items.summary:
- Moonvalley launched Marey, an AI video generator for Hollywood studios, aiming to speed up production and reduce costs.
- Marey is unique due to its exclusive training data from licensed content, avoiding copyright issues.
- The model outputs high-definition video, addressing challenges faced by other models that typically use lower-quality footage.
- Unlike typical video generators, Marey allows filmmakers to use storyboards or keyframes for input, enhancing professional workflows.
- Pilot programs are underway with brands to generate custom video content, including commercials.

items.title: NASA’s new AI satellites could revolutionize disaster response
A new wearable from dating app RAW promises to track your partner’s emotions in real time
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- The RAW ring, developed by the dating app RAW, allows couples to track each other’s emotions in real time.
- The wearable tracks heartbeat, vitals, and detects emotional cues, functioning like a digital mood ring for partners.
- Expected to launch in late 2025 or early 2026, with pricing yet to be announced.
- Concerns exist regarding privacy and relationship dynamics as couples share emotional data.

items.title: Box CEO Aaron Levie finds a middle ground on tech policy during Trump’s second term
How the Trump administration plans to use algorithms to target protesters
items.summary:
- The U.S. State Department is planning to use technology to suppress protests against the Trump administration.
- The "Catch and Revoke" plan by Marco Rubio aims to utilize AI analysis of social media to revoke visas of foreign nationals.
- Mahmoud Khalil, a former grad student, is highlighted as a target for this initiative due to his participation in protests.
- Experts warn that using AI to analyze social media could lead to significant false positives and raise privacy concerns.

items.title: Military AI is here. Some experts are worried
items.summary:
- Scale AI awarded a multimillion-dollar deal to develop Thunderforge for the U.S. Department of Defense.
- Thunderforge aims to integrate AI into military operational planning with claims of providing the U.S. military leaders a technological advantage.
- Experts express concern over the potential catastrophic outcomes of AI in military use, with predictions of risks to human extinction.
- Call for international collaboration and guidelines to manage AI in military settings to prevent destructive applications.

items.title: Dubbing is terrible. Can AI fix it?
Trump is buying a Tesla after years of bashing EVs
‘A world without Caesars’: Bluesky CEO takes a swipe at Meta’s Mark Zuckerberg and tech plutocrats
items.author: Jay Graber
items.summary:
- Bluesky CEO Jay Graber criticized Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg at SXSW, wearing a shirt that said ‘Mundus sine Caesaribus’ (A world without Caesars).
- The shirt design mirrored Zuckerberg's previous shirt that read ‘Aut Zuck aut nihil’.
- Graber emphasized the importance of decentralized platforms prioritizing users over profits, stating that users could leave if Bluesky were controlled by a billionaire.
- Bluesky, based on the open-source AT Protocol, has over 33 million users, but is still far from the user base of Meta's platforms, which total 3.35 billion daily active users.

items.title: What comes after search? Cloudflare’s CEO says that’s an ‘existential’ question for the internet
items.author: Anna-Louise Jackson
items.summary:
- Google has simplified finding answers, impacting media companies negatively.
- Matthew Prince, CEO of Cloudflare, emphasizes the need for a new business model for the internet as AI changes search dynamics.
- He notes that content scarcity and monetization are crucial for creators' sustainability against AI systems.
- Cloudflare aims to enhance online information access while ensuring fair compensation for creators.

items.title: Amazon will soon be streaming Trump’s ‘The Apprentice’ reality show
items.summary:
- Amazon will start streaming *The Apprentice* starting Monday, with the first season available now and subsequent seasons airing weekly until late April.
- The show debuted in 2004 and was pivotal in boosting Donald Trump’s public persona and business image.
- Trump highlighted the nostalgic value and learning experiences from the show in a statement released by Amazon.
- This move reflects Amazon's efforts to mend relations with Trump, following a complicated history during his presidency.

items.title: What the breakup of Google could mean for Apple and other tech companies
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- The Justice Department suggested Google be forced to sell the Chrome web browser following a ruling that determined it was a monopoly.
- Google’s revenue share payment to Apple as the default search engine in Safari was estimated at $20 billion in 2022, impacting Apple's operating profit.
- Apple intervened in the government case against Google but was denied by a judge, raising concerns about future financial dependencies and legal repercussions for other tech companies like Meta and Amazon.

items.title: People are paying up for this $39 yogurt that went viral on TikTok
items.summary:
- A yogurt called Coconut Cult is priced at $39 for a 16-ounce jar and has become a viral trend on TikTok.
- Influencers are promoting its probiotic benefits, reporting improvements in bloating and digestion, but some users criticize its sour taste.
- The yogurt is marketed more as a probiotic supplement rather than a standard snack, containing about 50 billion CFUs per ounce, significantly higher than regular yogurts.
- The product is experiencing high demand, causing shipping delays of up to three weeks as production ramps up to meet this demand.

items.title: 6 free LinkedIn Learning courses to help you find a new job
items.author: Doug Aamoth
items.summary:
- The job market is challenging, with many individuals facing layoffs.
- LinkedIn Learning offers free courses to help job seekers enhance their skills and confidence.
- Six recommended courses include:
  - **Polish up your résumé**: A 2.5-hour course on creating effective résumés, including formatting, keywords, common mistakes, and using action verbs.

items.title: How science is individualizing pregnancy risks
Why we’re ushering in a new era in pregnancy health
items.author: Maneesh Jain
items.summary:
- Lindsay Orr faced preeclampsia during pregnancy, leading to long-term health issues post-delivery.
- U.S. lags behind other nations in addressing the maternal health crisis, with 20% of pregnant women experiencing complications.
- Current prenatal care model has not changed significantly in 100 years, despite rising rates of complications like preeclampsia and preterm birth.
- Mirvie’s study analyzed 11,000 pregnancies, uncovering biological insights to predict risks of pregnancy complications.
- Personalized medicine in pregnancy can improve outcomes and reduce complications through tailored care plans and monitoring methods.

items.title: Tesla stock plummets but its sky-high valuation persists. Here’s why
SEC to abandon plan for crypto firms to register as trading systems
Cybertruck owners are joining a Facebook support group—and want to be a protected class
items.summary:
- Cybertruck owners report experiencing harassment and violence due to their vehicle choice, including threats and mockery.
- One owner has called for congressional action to classify such harassment as a hate crime, citing personal experiences of being targeted.
- A Facebook group for Cybertruck owners shares incidents of attacks, including a video of cheese being thrown at a Cybertruck.
- Police are responsive to the concerns, with reports of police protection at public events involving Cybertrucks.
- Protests against Tesla and Elon Musk have escalated, with calls for Tesla owners to divest from the brand due to Musk's actions.

items.title: How farmers are using AI on vineyards to make wine
Nissan is testing driverless vehicles in city streets
items.author: Yuri Kageyama
items.summary:
- Nissan's driverless technology utilizes 14 cameras, 9 radars, and 6 LiDar sensors installed in its vehicles.
- The technology is being tested in Yokohama, with plans to deploy 20 vehicles in the area in the coming years.
- The current testing stage is categorized as Level Two automation, requiring a human operator to intervene if necessary.
- Nissan aims to reach Level Four automation by 2029 or 2030, allowing for operation without human backup.
- Japan is competing with global leaders in autonomous driving, notably China and the U.S.
- The country faces challenges such as high public expectations for service quality and the need to address safety concerns around driverless technology.
- Prominent figures, including professors in the field, emphasize the importance of addressing edge cases for the future success of autonomous vehicles.

items.title: Social media might be making you sweat—literally
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Researchers from Durham University studied the physiological effects of scrolling social media, particularly Instagram.
- 54 young adults were monitored while browsing Instagram for 15 minutes; heart rates slowed but sweating increased compared to reading a news article.
- Interruptions from scrolling did not help; participants remained stressed and anxious, showing withdrawal-like symptoms similar to those experienced by addicts.
- Over half of Americans plan to reduce phone usage by 2025, with average daily screen time increasing to 5 hours and 16 minutes by 2024.

items.title: HUD is eyeing a crypto experiment. Some government workers are concerned
items.summary:
- The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) is considering using cryptocurrency for federal grants and is exploring blockchain technology for monitoring.
- Concerns are raised among HUD officials about the risks of paying grant recipients in cryptocurrency, highlighting its association with financial speculation and potential harm.
- The proposal is being pushed by HUD's principal deputy CFO, Irving Dennis, with involvement from the consulting firm EY. 
- The blockchain initiative coincides with a pro-crypto stance from the Trump administration, which has shown support for the crypto industry.

items.title: I tried out a bunch of the AI assistants. Here’s what you need to know about each one
items.summary:
- Overview of various AI assistants including ChatGPT, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, Anthropic Claude, DeepSeek, Grok, Perplexity, Duck.ai, and others.
- Each assistant has unique features, integrations, and pricing models.
- Notable features like voice modes, emotion recognition, web search, and document interaction are highlighted for each assistant.
- Pricing ranges from free basic access to premium plans costing up to $30 per month.

items.title: AI Slop is Suffocating the Web, Says a New Study
items.author: Yaohui Zhang
items.summary:
- A new study analyzes over 300 million documents showing AI-generated content on the rise across various sectors.
- Following the release of ChatGPT, AI involvement in customer complaints increased tenfold.
- Certain states like Arkansas and Missouri are more likely to use AI for writing complaints, while others like West Virginia and Vermont show lower usage.
- Researchers developed a statistical framework to detect AI-generated text with over 96.7% accuracy.
- Concerns are raised about AI constraining human creativity due to the overwhelming amount of AI-generated content.

items.title: 3 Simple Ways to Fight Back Against Spam Calls
items.summary:
- Adding your phone number to the [National Do Not Call Registry](https://www.donotcall.gov/index.html) can significantly reduce spam calls. It takes a month for telemarketers to remove you from their lists after registration.
- Utilizing call-blocking features on smartphones can help manage unwanted calls. Most smartphones allow blocking of individual numbers, effective against repeat offenders.
- Additional options may be needed, as the Do Not Call list is often ineffective against scammers and illegal telemarketers.

items.title: TikTok’s ‘recession brunette’ trend signals tough economic times
items.summary:
- Many blondes are returning to their natural hair color, which is seen as a reflection of economic struggles.
- TikTok videos showcase users commenting on their hair roots as indicators of financial health.
- Similar trends occurred during the 2007-2009 recession when celebrities embraced darker roots.
- One in six Americans report spending more on beauty than they can afford, leading to reduced salon visits.
- Hairstylist costs are high, making blonde upkeep a luxury, thus promoting the trend of 'recession brunette'.

items.title: Back from Extinction: How Colossal Is Charting a New Frontier in Genomics
items.author: Ben Lamm, Joe Manganiello, Kc Ifeanyi
items.summary:
- Colossal Biosciences launched in 2021 and is valued at $10.2 billion.
- The company focuses on de-extinction, including the revival of the woolly mammoth and dodo.
- Their mission also aims to combat biodiversity loss and regenerate degraded ecosystems and climates.

items.title: This secret site lets you try DeepSeek on a trustworthy U.S. server
items.summary:
- The article discusses the shortcomings of current AI tools, highlighting a prevalent sense of exhaustion from AI hype.
- It introduces a new AI tool, DeepSeek, which is touted as impressive and free to use without any subscription.
- Readers are encouraged to try the tool themselves to experience its effectiveness.

items.title: iPad shoppers beware: One of the new models is not like the others
items.summary:
- Apple has updated its iPad lineup, introducing a third-generation iPad Air and an eleventh-generation iPad.
- The entry-level iPad has not been refreshed since October 2022.
- The new iPad (2025) lacks support for Apple Intelligence AI platform due to having only 6GB of memory and the A16 chip.
- Apple Intelligence requires at least 8GB of memory, making the new iPad incompatible with the platform.
- This decision may be aimed at encouraging customers to purchase higher-priced models like the iPad mini and iPad Air.

items.title: YouTube is cracking down on gambling content. Here’s what’s changing
items.summary:
- YouTube announced a new policy banning links to "unapproved" gambling websites, effective March 19.
- Gambling content will be restricted for users under 18 and may take down videos promising guaranteed returns.
- Exceptions exist for content related to online sports betting and in-person gambling.
- This change is part of broader efforts to protect younger viewers, including improved age estimation technology.
- YouTube has previously banned gambling ads in specific placements and aims to address the surge of gambling content on its platform.

items.title: Deepfake scammers are hijacking TikTok’s wellness craze to sell dubious health products
items.summary:
- Deepfake technology is being used for scams on TikTok, where fake influencers promote dubious wellness products.
- A report from Media Matters identified multiple TikTok accounts using deepfake influencers and fake storytimes to sell these products with no scientific backing.
- One deleted account had over 245,000 followers and promoted a batana oil purported to enhance hair growth, featuring an AI-generated influencer.
- Scammers exploit popular TikTok formats like #storytime to market their products, often tying them to personal, relatable struggles.
- The report highlights a narrative designed to resonate with viewers, linking infertility and a questionable supplement to garner trust before selling a product.

items.title: Trump Signs Executive Order to Establish Bitcoin Reserve
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- President Donald Trump signed an executive order to create a government reserve of Bitcoin.
- The U.S. government will retain approximately 200,000 seized Bitcoins as a store of value, termed a digital Fort Knox.
- The executive order calls for a full accounting of Bitcoin holdings, with past sales valued at a potential loss of about $17 billion.
- Trump, once a Bitcoin skeptic, has adopted a pro-crypto stance, hosting a White House Crypto Summit and advocating for industry-friendly legislation.
- The order also establishes a "U.S. Digital Asset Stockpile" for other seized cryptocurrencies like XRP, Solana, and Cardano.

items.title: SpaceX’s Starship explodes again, with wreckage seen from Florida
items.author: Marcia Dunn
items.summary:
- SpaceX launched another Starship rocket but lost contact minutes into the flight, resulting in the spacecraft breaking apart over Florida.
- The rocket reached nearly 90 miles in altitude before its failure; wreckage was seen near Cape Canaveral.
- The incident leads to an investigation by the FAA, and flights at Orlando International Airport were temporarily grounded due to debris in the area.

items.title: Spotify’s leaning hard into video podcasts. Here’s how creators are adapting
items.summary:
- Spotify has opened a new revenue stream for podcasters who upload video content.
- Podcasting is shifting from audio-only to video formats, inspired by YouTube's success with one billion monthly podcast viewers.
- Spotify is rolling out new features and monetization tools, including a Partner Program for video podcasters that allows them to earn from premium subscriber streams.
- Jordan Newman, Spotify’s senior director of content partnerships, stated the company is encouraging video content to align with audience and creator trends.
- Fast Company interviewed various creators to understand their views on Spotify's video push, highlighting differing opinions between video adopters and audio-only podcasters.

items.title: Google’s ‘quiet’ decision to remove cultural events from its Calendar app sent a loud message
items.summary:
- Google Calendar will not display several cultural events, including South by Southwest (SXSW), Women’s History Month, and International Women’s Day.
- The removal aligns with a broader trend of companies distancing themselves from DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) terms.
- Users highlighted the absence of cultural observances like Black History Month, leading to scrutiny of Google's recent changes.

items.title: Creative Leaders Share How They're Harnessing AI in Work
items.author: Fast Company
items.summary:
- The article discusses an in-depth survey on how creative professionals use AI in their work.
- AI is now a routine part of the creative process for many, making a return to working without it nearly impossible.
- Respondents acknowledge AI as a powerful, though sometimes error-prone, collaborator in enhancing the creative process.
- A diverse cohort of creatives responded, with the majority being founders or in C-suite positions!
- Key industries represented include tech (22%), design (16%), and entertainment (14%).
- 83% of respondents integrate AI into their creative processes; 48% rely on it for most or all projects.

items.title: Glydways wants to reinvent transit—no more than four passengers at a time
Remembering how 18F modernized government technology
items.summary:
- Healthcare.gov launched in October 2013, facing technical issues with only 2,000 concurrent users.
- 18F was established on March 19, 2014, to modernize government digital services, derived from GSA's address, 1800 F Street.
- The Trump administration eliminated 18F on March 1, 2025, raising concerns about the future of government technology services.
- 18F improved public service technology, supporting projects like IRS Direct File, serving 30 million taxpayers in the 2025 season.

items.title: Why weird JD Vance memes have taken over the internet
items.summary:
- The meeting between Ukrainian President Zelenskyy and U.S. officials, including JD Vance, sparked a wave of memes surrounding Vance's reaction.
- Vance's boyish photo was altered to appear overly cherubic, leading to widespread mockery across social media platforms.
- The meme's evolution has included various cultural references, highlighting its bipartisan appeal among both critics and supporters of Vance.

items.title: How this sex-forward gay cruising site finally launched an Apple-approved iOS app
Gig Companies are backing Trump’s Labor Secretary nominee. Here’s what that means for workers
items.summary:
- America's largest gig companies are backing Trump's nominees for the Department of Labor, which could influence worker classification in the gig economy.
- Flex, a lobbying group with members like Uber, Lyft, and DoorDash, supports Lori Chavez-DeRemer and Keith Sonderling for key positions in the department.
- A change in labor classification from independent contractors to employees could significantly increase labor costs for gig companies, affecting their profitability and operational models.

items.title: TSMC’s $100 billion U.S. commitment could calm Taiwan tensions
items.summary:
- TSMC will invest $100 billion in U.S. operations over the next ten years.
- The investment will fund three new fabrication plants, R&D center, and advanced packaging facilities.
- TSMC has already committed $65 billion for chip facilities near Phoenix, Arizona.
- The U.S. government currently has no tariffs on imports from Taiwan but considers tariffs on Taiwanese semiconductors.
- TSMC's investment may help prevent the imposition of such tariffs by the Trump administration.
- TSMC plays a vital role in global semiconductor supply chains, heavily relying on U.S. customers like Nvidia.
- TSMC’s expansion abroad is driven by geopolitical tensions between the U.S. and China.

items.title: The Trump administration just cut Defense Department grants that research terrorism and drug trafficking
items.summary:
- Grants from the Department of Defense's Minerva Research Initiative are being terminated, risking research and employment for many involved.
- The Minerva program has funded crucial social science research on national security since 2008, addressing topics like Russian propaganda and U.S. military deployments.
- The recent funding cuts represent a shift in priorities under the Trump administration, despite the program's bipartisan support and relatively low annual cost.

items.title: Salesforce’s AI agents can decode tariffs in minutes
How Audiomack became an unlikely Spotify competitor
items.author: Brian Zisook, Dave Macli
items.summary:
- Audiomack is gaining popularity as a competitor to Spotify, especially in West Africa.
- The platform's current No. 1 album belongs to Nigerian artist Seyi Vibez, with 1.8 billion plays.
- Audiomack has 40 million monthly listeners, with half from Africa, demonstrating its strong local market presence.
- Founded in 2012 by Zisook and Macli to help local hip-hop DJs distribute mixtapes, Audiomack's growth surged in 2019 with West African users.
- The company hired a local team in Nigeria to better understand the market and avoid viewing Africa as a singular entity.

items.title: YouTube is doubling down on ‘bedtime’ reminders. Do they work?
items.summary:
- Teenage YouTube users globally will receive automatic reminders to go to bed and take breaks from screens.
- These reminders, first introduced in the U.S. seven years ago, are now toggled on by default for minors as of 2023.
- Effectiveness of the reminders is questionable, as users can easily dismiss them.
- YouTube's 'take a break' notification began in 2018, with over three billion warnings sent by 2020.
- Concerns about teen mental health have grown, prompting YouTube to make reminders more prominent in 2023.
- TikTok has also implemented similar features for screen time management for users under 18.

items.title: 'Dark woke' is the internet’s answer to Trump-style politics
items.summary:
- The term 'dark woke' emerged post-Trump's reelection, urging liberals to adopt a tougher, more aggressive approach.
- Examples include AOC's provocative comments and new strategies among Democrats like Robert Garcia.
- Critics argue that 'dark woke' often equates to using slurs under the guise of leftist language, reflecting a shift towards meaner politics influenced by Trump's style.

items.title: Utah just passed the country’s first age verification bill for app stores. But the fight isn’t over
items.summary:
- Utah has passed the App Store Accountability Act, mandating age verification for app store users and parental consent for minors.
- The bill is headed to Governor Spencer Cox's desk and reflects ongoing tensions between app stores and social media companies.
- Advocates argue the law will help protect children online, while critics believe it infringes on privacy and First Amendment rights.
- Significant push from parent groups contributed to the legislation's success, according to the sponsoring state representative Jim Dunnigan.
- The Digital Childhood Alliance sees this as part of a growing movement for accountability in the digital space.

items.title: This shaving brand was banned on TikTok, so it started an OnlyFans
items.summary:
- London-based razor brand [Nimbi](https://nimbi.supply/pages/our-ethos?contact_posted=true#ContactForm) faced low TikTok views due to a shadowban on the word "razor".
- Co-founder Anna Reid jokingly suggested using OnlyFans for marketing, leading to an unconventional approach.
- Nimbi posts instructional content on OnlyFans, providing educational techniques rather than sexualized content.
- Currently, Nimbi is the top seller in Erewhon's personal care category and will expand to more than 900 Target stores on March 1, 2024.
- Nimbi's razors are eco-friendly, made from waste wood pulp, pine oil, and clay, differentiating them from traditional plastic razors.
